November 1436, Shortly After Dawn

The birthing chamber holds the quiet that follows great effort. Clean linens have replaced the soiled ones, and the room smells of lavender and the particular warmth of new life. Princess Juana sleeps in her cradle near the bed, dark hair already thick like her mother's, her tiny fingers curled in the unconscious grip of infants.

Queen Lucia reclines against banked pillows, exhausted but alert. The color has returned to her face—the midwives remarked on her remarkable constitution. Three children in three years of marriage, each delivery smoother than the last, each recovery swifter. She watches you with grey-green eyes that hold both tenderness and that particular sharpness she has never lost, even in moments like these.

The chief midwife and her assistants move quietly at the edges of the room, tidying instruments and preparing the posset wine that will help Lucia's milk come in. Through the narrow windows, the first grey light of a November morning seeps into Toledo.

Lucia's eyebrow rises—that particular arch you have come to know well. "Isaac? Now?" She glances at the sleeping infant, at the midwives still bustling about their quiet tasks. "You wish to speak with your shadow-man while the sheets still carry the scent of labor?"

Her voice carries no accusation, only the wry observation of a woman who knows her husband's mind turns to business even in moments of tenderness. She shifts against the pillows, wincing slightly at a twinge of discomfort.

"Go, then. I will not be lonely." She nods toward the cradle. "Juana and I have much to discuss about the questionable judgment of naming oneself after one's father. And you—" a tired smile, "—you have been still too long already. I can see it. Whatever you are planning, it has been building behind your eyes these past months."

She reaches for your hand, squeezes it once. "Send word when you are ready for the world to meet your daughter. The Archbishop will want to discuss her baptism."

You find Isaac in his customary place—not quite in the royal quarters, not quite in the servants' passages, but in the small chamber between them that most men would not even notice existed. He rises when you enter, his movements economical as always. The years have worn at him—more grey in his beard now, deeper lines around those watchful eyes—but the sharpness remains undiminished.

"Your Majesty." A slight bow. "I am told there is another princess in the world. Congratulations."

He waits. Isaac has never been one to fill silence unnecessarily.
Do you have the poison? Are there special instructions to administer it?

Isaac's expression does not change. He moves to the door, checks the passage beyond, then closes it with a soft click. When he speaks, his voice drops to something barely above a breath.

"I have it."

He reaches into his doublet and produces a small wooden box, unremarkable in every way—the sort of thing that might hold a signet ring or a minor keepsake. He opens it to reveal a ring of modest gold, set with a dark stone that might be onyx or jet. Nothing that would draw a second glance on a king's hand.

"The stone twists." He demonstrates, and you see the tiny compartment beneath—a hollow no larger than a pea. "One full turn to the left, press, and the spring releases a single drop. The compound is colorless. In wine, it is undetectable. In food with strong spices—Aragonese cooking, Neapolitan fare—equally so."

He closes the box and sets it on the small table between you.

"Instructions." His dark eyes meet yours. "Never more than one drop per encounter. The compound accumulates in the liver and kidneys. Given what we know of Alfonso's existing damage—the fevers, the drinking, the old wounds that never healed properly—the symptoms will be indistinguishable from the natural progression of a body worn by years of campaign and excess."

Isaac pauses, weighing his next words.

"Three encounters, perhaps four, spread over two years. More frequent, and a skilled physician might notice a pattern. Less frequent, and the body may clear what has been given. Barcelona in spring. Then Naples or Rome when opportunity presents. Then again a year hence." He spreads his hands slightly. "By the time Alfonso's health fails—and it will fail—no one will think to look for a cause beyond what everyone already whispers: that the King of Aragon has lived too hard and too recklessly."

He reaches into his doublet again and produces a smaller vial, no larger than a woman's fingernail.

"This refills the compartment. Three doses remain after the ring is loaded. Keep it somewhere no servant will find it—not with your medicines, not with your jewelry. Somewhere only you know."

Isaac's voice carries no judgment now. That conversation happened months ago, in the darkness of a Toledo night. He made his reservations known; you made your decision. Now there is only the work.

"The ring is designed to be worn daily. If you wear it only when meeting Alfonso, someone may eventually notice the pattern. Wear it always, or not at all."

He falls silent, waiting.

I let my children ride in the carriage, or ride on a horse if they want.

The spring of 1437 unfolds like a tapestry woven in Castile's favor.

You depart Toledo in late March under skies scrubbed clean by overnight rain, the roads firm enough for travel but not yet baked to summer dust. The column moves at the pace of the youngest children—steady, unhurried, a king who has time enough to show his realm to his heirs.

Fernando, not yet four, insists on riding. You place him before you on your own horse for the first league out of Toledo, his small hands gripping the pommel with fierce concentration. He does not laugh or shout as other children might. He studies—the movement of the horse, the way you hold the reins, the rhythm of hooves on packed earth.

"When can I have my own horse, Father?" he asks, voice serious.

"When your legs are long enough to reach the stirrups."

He considers this, nods once, and returns to his study of horsemanship.

Catalina, by contrast, holds court from the carriage. At five years old, she has already learned that a window makes a stage. When you pass through villages, she waves with precisely calibrated grace—not too eager, not too remote. The peasants who line the roads to watch the royal procession pass find themselves waving back at a little girl with dark curls and her mother's bearing, and they remember it.

Guadalajara

The Mendoza receive you with full honors. Don Íñigo López de Mendoza—poet, warrior, and patriarch of one of Castile's great houses—rides out personally to escort you into the city. His eyes miss nothing: the healthy children, the beautiful queen, the king who wears his authority as easily as his plain traveling clothes.

"Your Majesty's family does credit to the realm," he says, and means it.

That night, at a modest banquet, Catalina sings. Word has spread of her gift since the Portuguese visit, and Don Íñigo requests the honor. She performs the same lullaby—Duérmete, niño pequeño—and the great hall falls silent. When she finishes, Don Íñigo's wife weeps openly.

"The House of Trastámara," Don Íñigo murmurs to you afterward, "has been blessed beyond measure."

Zaragoza

You enter Aragon proper, and here the welcome shifts—still warm, but watching. These are Alfonso's lands in all but name, administered in his absence by men loyal to the Aragonese crown. They receive you correctly, formally, with the precise hospitality owed to a fellow sovereign who is also their king's brother-in-law and heir.

But the children break through formality.

Fernando, riding now on a small palfrey led by a groom, draws admiration from the Aragonese knights. He sits his horse like a boy twice his age, back straight, eyes forward. "A warrior born," one of them says, loud enough for you to hear. They do not know about his reluctance with blades, his preference for books. They see only the magnificent physical presence—Juan's chin, Isabel's eyes, and something else entirely his own.

Catalina charms the Archbishop of Zaragoza into giving her a blessing and a small golden cross. Teresa, just two, toddles through the episcopal palace leaving chaos and enchantment in her wake. Even Bianca, quiet and watchful at nearly three, earns smiles for her solemn gravity.

Lucia moves through it all with effortless grace, her Italian sophistication perfectly modulated to Spanish sensibilities. She speaks with the Aragonese ladies about children and household management, never once mentioning politics—and in doing so, accomplishes more diplomacy than a dozen formal negotiations.

Word rides ahead to Barcelona. Messengers carry reports to Alfonso: The King of Castile approaches with his queen and five children. The heir rides like a knight. The eldest princess sings like an angel. The dynasty flourishes.

The Descent to the Sea

The final stretch of road winds down from the Aragonese highlands toward the Mediterranean. The air changes—salt and warmth replacing the dry wind of the meseta. The children crowd the carriage windows to catch their first glimpse of the sea.

Fernando sees it first. "Father," he calls from his palfrey, pointing east. "Is that—?"

The Mediterranean stretches to the horizon, hammered silver under the spring sun. You remember your own first sight of it, years ago. Now you watch your son discover it, his serious face breaking into rare wonder.

"That is the sea, Fernando. And beyond it—Constantinople, where your father earned his title. Rome, where the Holy Father dwells. Naples, where your uncle now makes war. The whole of Christendom, and the lands beyond."

He absorbs this in silence. Then: "Will I see Constantinople someday?"

"God willing."

Barcelona — April 1437

You enter Barcelona in the second week of April, the royal column winding through streets lined with citizens who have heard the stories filtering down from Zaragoza and Guadalajara. The Castilian king with his beautiful Italian queen. The little princess who sings. The heir who rides like a born knight.

Alfonso V has sent an honor guard to meet you at the city gates—Aragonese knights in the red and gold bars of their kingdom, their captain bearing formal greetings from the king. Alfonso himself waits at the Palau Reial Major, the ancient seat of the Counts of Barcelona.

The captain's eyes move over your family as he delivers his prepared words. You see him counting: five children, all healthy, the queen already recovered from her latest birth. He sees what Alfonso will see—a dynasty ascendant, a line secured, a future written in the faces of the children who watch him with varying degrees of curiosity and imperial disdain.

The message has been delivered before you speak a single word to your brother-in-law.

The Palau Reial Major rises ahead, its medieval towers sharp against the spring sky. Somewhere within, Alfonso V of Aragon—conqueror, schemer, the man whose kingdoms you will inherit and whose death you carry on your finger—waits to receive his family.
I enter Barcelona.

The Palau Reial Major

The ancient palace rises from the heart of Barcelona's Gothic quarter, its stones darkened by centuries of sea air and Mediterranean sun. You pass through the Plaça del Rei—the King's Square—where Aragonese banners snap in the spring breeze alongside the arms of Castile, hung in honor of your arrival.

The great doors stand open. Inside, the Saló del Tinell awaits—the vast throne room where the Counts of Barcelona held court for generations, its rounded arches soaring overhead like the ribs of some great stone beast.

Alfonso V stands at the far end.

He has aged since you last saw him. The Italian campaigns have carved new lines into his face, and there is grey now at his temples that was not there before. But the energy remains—that restless vitality that drove him across the Mediterranean to chase a crown. He wears cloth-of-gold over crimson, the arms of Aragon quartered with those of Sicily and Naples, a statement of ambition stitched in silk.

Beside him stands your sister María, Queen of Aragon. She is thirty-six now, her beauty settling into the handsome severity of middle age. Her eyes find you as you enter, and something flickers there—relief, perhaps, or longing, or the complicated weight of a sister who has not seen her brother in years.

The court of Aragon fills the hall: nobles, clergy, officials, all watching the King of Castile approach with his family arrayed behind him. Lucia walks at your side, Juana in her arms. The nurses carry Bianca and Teresa. Fernando walks on his own, small but straight-backed, his eyes fixed forward. Catalina holds her brother's hand, for once subdued by the grandeur around her.

Alfonso descends the steps from the dais. His stride is confident, proprietary—a king in his own hall, receiving a guest he considers an equal but perhaps not quite a rival. Not yet.

He stops before you. The hall falls silent.

"Brother." Alfonso's voice carries easily in the vaulted space, pitched for the audience as much as for you. His arms open, and he embraces you—the formal embrace of kings, cheek to cheek, hands gripping shoulders. You smell wine on his breath, faint but present. This close, you can see the yellowing at the corners of his eyes, the slight tremor in his hands that he hides well but cannot entirely conceal.

He pulls back, holding you at arm's length, studying your face.

"You look well. Kingly, even. The years have been generous." A smile, charming and calculated. "And this—" his gaze moves past you to Lucia, to the children, "—this is the dynasty I have heard so much about."

He releases you and turns to your wife, taking her free hand and bowing over it with courtly grace.

"Queen Lucia. Italy's loss remains Castile's gain. You are as beautiful as the poets claim." He straightens, glancing at the infant in her arms. "And this would be the newest addition? Juana, yes? Named for her father, I am told." A flicker of amusement. "Vanity becomes you, brother."

Then his attention shifts to the children. He crouches—slowly, you notice, with a slight stiffness in his knees—to bring himself to Fernando's level.

"And you must be Fernando. Prince of Asturias. Heir to Castile." Alfonso studies your son with open appraisal. "They tell me you ride already. That you sit a horse like a man grown."

Fernando meets the King of Aragon's gaze without flinching.

Alfonso's smile widens. He straightens and looks to Catalina, who watches him with those calculating dark eyes.

"And the famous Catalina. The one who sings." He tilts his head. "Will you sing for your uncle, little one, before your visit ends?"

María has not moved from the dais. She watches the scene below, hands folded, face composed. But her eyes keep returning to you—to the brother she has not seen in years, who has become something more than the young king she remembers.

Alfonso turns back to you, spreading his hands to encompass the hall, the palace, the city beyond.

"Welcome to Barcelona, brother. We have much to discuss—Naples, the Turk, the future of Christendom." His smile sharpens, just slightly. "But first, let us be family. There will be time enough for politics."

He gestures toward the dais, toward María, toward the seats prepared for you beside the Aragonese throne.

"Come. My queen has waited long enough to embrace her brother."
We have dinner and we catch up. I let my sister enjoy her little cousins.

The formal reception dissolves into something warmer as the evening unfolds.

The great hall gives way to a smaller dining chamber—still grand by any measure, but intimate enough for family. Tapestries depicting the conquest of Mallorca line the walls, Aragonese history woven in silk and gold thread. Candles soften the spring twilight filtering through tall windows that overlook the sea.

María comes alive among the children in a way she never did on the dais. She kneels on the floor in her queen's gown, heedless of the silk, building block towers with Teresa while Bianca watches with solemn approval. When Fernando approaches to show her a small wooden knight he has carried from Toledo, she examines it with genuine interest, asking him about his horse, his studies, his favorite books. Her questions are careful, hungry—the questions of a woman who has no children of her own and feels that absence keenly.

"He has your eyes," she tells Lucia quietly, watching Fernando return to his seat. "But his manner is... gentler. Thoughtful." She glances at you, something unreadable in her expression. "You were never so still at his age, brother. You were always climbing things. Escaping your tutors."

Catalina, predictably, gravitates toward Alfonso. The King of Aragon seems genuinely charmed by her—or perhaps recognizes a kindred spirit. They conduct a negotiation over honeyed almonds that ends with Catalina in possession of the entire bowl and Alfonso laughing in a way that seems, for a moment, unguarded.

"This one will be trouble," he announces to the table. "Mark my words. She will have kings fighting over her hand before she is twelve."

He drinks steadily through dinner—good Aragonese wine, cup after cup, refilled by attentive servants. You notice how his hand trembles slightly when he reaches for the pitcher himself, how he shifts in his seat as though unable to find comfort. The yellowing in his eyes is more pronounced in candlelight. When he laughs, there is sometimes a catch in his breath, a pause that suggests pain suppressed.

But his mind remains sharp. Between courses, between the children's interruptions and María's quiet questions, Alfonso speaks of Naples—the endless siege, the Angevin resistance, the Pope's wavering support. He speaks of the Ottoman advance, of Constantinople's desperate embassies, of the failures of Christendom to mount any coherent response.

"Except you, of course." He raises his cup toward you, an ironic salute. "The Defensor Romaniae. The man who actually went." There is something in his voice—admiration, perhaps, or envy, or the wariness of a king who recognizes a rival's rising star. "Tell me, brother. Was it worth it? The knights, the gold, the months away from your kingdom? For a city that will fall anyway, sooner or later?"

The table falls quiet. María's hand pauses on Teresa's hair. Lucia's eyes meet yours for a moment.

Alfonso waits, cup raised, watching you over its rim.

Roll: 83 — Alarming Signs

You watch Alfonso across the table, and you see what his court has learned not to see.

It is in the small things, the moments between performance. When Alfonso reaches for his cup, the tremor is not merely unsteady—it is the shake of muscles that no longer fully obey. When he laughs at Catalina's negotiation over almonds, the laughter catches, hitches, and for a heartbeat his hand presses against his side before he masters himself. His servants refill his wine without being asked because they have learned the rhythm of his need—not the indulgence of a man who enjoys drink, but the medicine of a man who requires it to function.

The yellowing in his eyes is jaundice. You have seen it before, in men whose livers failed them. The stiffness when he crouched to greet Fernando was not merely age—it was pain, joint-deep, the kind that never fully recedes.
